[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [State Sync: Transaction Ordering] [Ordering violation] Can the asynchronous nature of the event stream cause transaction responses to arrive out of order, breaking state sync assumptions about sequential processing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [State Sync: Chunk Size] [Chunk manipulation] Can an attacker request excessively large data chunks through malicious StorageServiceRequest parameters, causing memory exhaustion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [State Sync: Snapshot Security] [Snapshot poisoning] Can responses containing snapshot data be tampered with to cause syncing nodes to accept an invalid state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Concurrency: Channel Safety] [Channel races] Can race conditions between sending a request and closing the peer connection cause the ResponseSender to send to a closed channel? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Concurrency: Event Ordering] [Event reordering] Can the select_all() combinator cause events from different networks to interleave in ways that violate ordering assumptions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Concurrency: Fuse Safety] [Fuse termination] After the fused stream returns None once, is it guaranteed to return None forever, or can it resume producing events and cause logic errors? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Concurrency: Filter Map] [Filter race] Can the filter_map() operation race with network disconnections, causing events to be processed after the network is disconnected? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Concurrency: Response Race] [Response timing] Can delayed responses sent through ResponseSender arrive after the client has timed out and disconnected, causing resource waste? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Concurrency: Network ID] [Network ID race] Can the network_id captured in the closure at line 46 become stale if networks are reconfigured during operation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Attack: Amplification] [Request amplification] Can a small malicious request cause disproportionately large responses, enabling bandwidth amplification DoS attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Attack: Resource Exhaustion] [Stream exhaustion] Can an attacker create many network connections, each producing event streams that collectively exhaust memory through select_all()? (High)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Attack: Timing] [Timing side channel] Can response timing from ResponseSender::send() leak information about whether requested data exists in cache vs. storage? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Attack: Fingerprinting] [Protocol fingerprinting] Can attackers use protocol_id values to fingerprint the node's configuration or version, enabling targeted exploits? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Attack: Request Flooding] [Filter bypass flooding] Can attackers send high volumes of non-RPC events that get filtered by event_to_request(), wasting CPU on useless filtering? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Attack: Memory Pressure] [Boxed allocation] Does the boxed() stream conversion at line 55 create excessive heap allocations that can be exploited for memory pressure attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Attack: Connection Exhaustion] [Network limit bypass] Can attackers bypass per-peer connection limits by using multiple PeerNetworkId values to appear as different peers? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Attack: Response Blocking] [Response backpressure] Can a slow-reading peer cause ResponseSender::send() to block, preventing other peers from receiving responses? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Error: Network Partition] [Partial network failure] If some networks in the select_all() fail but others continue, can this cause partial state sync where only some peers can sync? (High)

[File: aptos-core/state-sync/storage-service/server/src/network.rs] [Error: Stream Termination] [Premature termination] Can the network_request_stream terminate unexpectedly due to underlying network errors, causing permanent loss of request processing? (Critical)
